chapter.htmlHeader: What are the complications?
chapter.htmlStringContent: • Adults, pregnant women, neonates, and immunocompromised people are more susceptible to serious complications [PHE, 2015; BMJ Best Practice, 2016].

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Complications in children
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Chickenpox is usually a self-limiting disease in healthy children, and complications are rare [Lichenstein, 2006; Papadopoulos, 2007; Papadopoulos, 2007]. However, complications may occur, including [Lichenstein, 2006; Gould, 2014; Sturgeon et al, 2015]:  
    • Skin bacterial superinfection (for example impetigo, furuncles, cellulitis, erysipelas, necrotizing fasciitis) and scarring. This may manifest as sudden high grade pyrexia (often after initial improvement), erythema, and tenderness surrounding the original chickenpox lesions.
    • Neurological complications (for example Reye's syndrome, acute cerebellar ataxia, encephalitis, meningoencephalitis, polyradiculitis, myelitis).
    • In rare cases, myocarditis, glomerulonephritis, appendicitis, pancreatitis, Henoch–Schönlein purpura, orchitis, arthritis, optic neuritis, iritis, and keratitis.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Complications in adults
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Chickenpox can be more serious in adults than in children [PHE, 2015], and adults with varicella are more likely to be admitted to hospital [Heininger and Seward, 2006].
  • Complications include pneumonia, hepatitis, and encephalitis [RCOG, 2015].
    • Smokers are particularly at risk of fulminating varicella pneumonia [PHE, 2015].
    • Of the mortality related to chickenpox in England and Wales, 80% occurs in adults [RCOG, 2015].
  • Older age is a risk factor for severe varicella disease, and the risk of dying from varicella is highest at extremes of age [Heininger and Seward, 2006].
  • Shingles can occur from reactivation of latent varicella-zoster infection [PHE, 2015].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Complications in pregnancy
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Complications for the mother:
    • Varicella in pregnancy can result in severe chickenpox. The mother is at increased risk of varicella pneumonia and other complications, compared with the general adult population [PHE, 2015].
    • Around 1 in 10 pregnant women with chickenpox develop pneumonia; the severity increases with later gestation [RCOG, 2015].
    • The case-fatality rate of pregnant women varies between case series, from 0–14% [RCOG, 2015].
  • Complications for the fetus:
    • Infection with varicella-zoster during the first 28 weeks of pregnancy can lead to intrauterine infection and fetal varicella syndrome (previously known as congenital varicella syndrome), which is characterized by one or more of [RCOG, 2015]:
      • Skin scarring in a dermatomal distribution.
      • Eye defects (for example microphthalmia, chorioretinitis, and cataracts).
      • Hypoplasia of the limbs.
      • Neurological abnormalities (microcephaly, cortical atrophy, learning difficulties, dysfunction of bowel and bladder sphincters).
      • The incidence of fetal varicella syndrome is less than 1% in the first 12 weeks, and around 2% between 13 and 20 weeks of pregnancy [PHE, 2015]. 
      • Cases of fetal varicella syndrome have also been reported in women between 20 and 28 weeks of gestation, indicating that there is a small risk of fetal varicella syndrome when a woman develops chickenpox after 20 weeks of pregnancy [RCOG, 2015]. The risk of fetal damage is likely to be lower than fetal varicella syndrome occurring in the first 20 weeks of pregnancy [PHE, 2015].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Complications in neonates
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Neonates are at increased risk of disseminated or haemorrhagic varicella [PHE, 2015].
  • If the mother becomes infected 1–4 weeks before delivery, up to half of babies will be infected; and around a quarter will develop clinical varicella of the newborn, even though they have passively acquired maternal antibody. If the baby is born up to 7 days before or 7 days after onset of the mother's rash, it is more likely to develop severe infection, which may be fatal [PHE, 2015; RCOG, 2015].
  • If maternal infection occurs at 20–27 weeks of pregnancy, the baby may develop shingles of infancy or early childhood due to reactivation of the primary in-utero infection [HPA, 2011].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Complications in immunocompromised people
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Severe disseminated chickenpox with haemorrhagic complications is more common in immunocompromised people than in other population groups [PHE, 2015].
  • Immunocompromised people with chickenpox are also at increased risk of pneumonia, encephalitis, disseminated intravascular coagulopathy, and hepatitis [CDC, 2016].
